The 'Warsaw Treaty Organization of Friendship, Cooperation, and Mutual
Assistance' (1955â1991), more commonly referred to as the 'Warsaw Pact', was a
mutual defense treaty between eight communist states of Central and Eastern
Europe in existence during the Cold War. The founding treaty was established
under the initiative of the Soviet Union and signed on 14 May 1955, in Warsaw.
The Warsaw Pact was the military complement to the Council for Mutual Economic
Assistance (CoMEcon), the regional economic organization for the communist
states of Central and Eastern Europe. The Warsaw Pact was in part a Soviet
military reaction to the integration of West Germany into NATO in 1955, per the
Paris Pacts of 1954.
categories: Foreign relations of the Soviet Union
